Just something I noticed, you said magnesium, but that was a measurement of manganese, which are two different things.  Manganese is a micromineral, while magnesium is a macromineral.  Your body needs larger amounts of magnesium, but too much manganese can cause brain/memory issues.

The only problem is that the Lifestraw has a 2 micron filter and will filter out bacteria and protozoa, but it will not filter out pesticides or viruses.  So when you live on a lake and think that you have an unlimited supply of water, your water supply is full of the pesticides that all of your neighbors put on their yard.  The best bet is to use it only as a last resort.

Little something to point out; You misread the label on the test strip kit as "Magnesium" when instead it reads Manganese. Manganese itself, as pointed out on the kit, is okay in small ppm, but in large quantities can cause tremors, muscle spasms, loss of appetite, as well as anemia. Definitely a reason to read EVERY part of the kit before use.

Magnesium is not the same as Manganese.
